standard_metadata.standard_description: Add and subtract fractions with unlike denominators (including mixed numbers) by replacing given fractions with equivalent fractions in such a way as to produce an equivalent sum or difference of fractions with like denominators.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Estimate to add and subtract fractions with different denominators

question.content: Carlos mixed $\dfrac2{10}\text{ L}$ of orange juice with $\dfrac18\text{ L}$ of pineapple juice.  **Determine a reasonable estimate of the total amount of juice Carlos mixed.**

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-half unit. A tape diagram is above the number line from the tick mark at zero to the tick mark at one.  The tape diagram is divided into four parts. The first two parts are equal in size and shaded. The next part is shaded. The fourth part is not shaded and not labeled. Together, the three shaded parts of the tape diagram are from the tick mark at zero to the left of the tick mark at one-half on the number line.

A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-half unit. A tape diagram is above the number line from the tick mark at zero to the tick mark at one.  The tape diagram is divided into four parts. The first two parts are equal in size and shaded. The next part is shaded. The fourth part is not shaded and not labeled. Together, the three shaded parts of the tape diagram are from the tick mark at zero to between the tick marks at one-half and 1 on the number line.

A number line labeled 0 to 2 with tick marks every one-half unit. A tape diagram is above the number line from the tick mark at zero to an unlabeled point between the tick marks at 1 and 1 and 1-half.  The tape diagram is divided into 3 parts. The first two parts are equal in size and shaded. The next part is shaded. Together, the three shaded parts of the tape diagram are from the tick mark at zero to the right of the tick mark at 1 on the number line.

hints.content: We can make an estimate by picturing each fraction:  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A tape diagram with two tapes of equal length. The top tape is divided into ten equal parts with each part labeled one-tenth. The first two parts are shaded. The bottom tape is divided into eight equal parts with each part labeled one-eighth. The first part is shaded. Below the diagram, a curved bracket across the tapes is labeled 1.

hints.content: To find the total amount of juice, we need to add $\tealE{\dfrac2{10}}$ and $\maroonE{\dfrac18}$.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 4 unequal parts. The first 2 parts are equal in size, and each is shaded and labeled one-tenth. The next part is shaded and labeled one-eighth. The last part is not shaded and not labeled. A curved bracket across the tape is labeled 1.

hints.content: We can compare our sum to benchmarks like ${\dfrac12}$ and $1$:   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-half unit. A tape diagram is above the number line from the tick mark at zero to the tick mark at one.  The tape diagram is divided into four parts. The first two parts are equal in size, shaded, and each labeled one-tenth. The next part is shaded and labeled one-eighth. The fourth part is not shaded and not labeled. Together, the three shaded parts of the tape diagram are from the tick mark at zero to the left of the tick mark at one-half of the number line.

hints.content: Our sum is less than $\dfrac12$.
The sum that shows less than $\dfrac12\text{ L}$ is a reasonable estimate for the amount of juice Carlos mixed.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-half unit. A tape diagram is above the number line from the tick mark at zero to the tick mark at one.  The tape diagram is divided into four parts. The first two parts are equal in size and shaded. The next part is shaded. The fourth part is not shaded and not labeled. Together, the three shaded parts of the tape diagram are from the tick mark at zero to the left of the tick mark at one-half on the number line.

question.content: Tony has $\dfrac2{3}$ of a bag of dark chocolate chips and $\dfrac45$ of a bag of white chocolate chips.  **Determine a reasonable estimate of the total amount of chocolate chips Tony has.**

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-half unit. A tape diagram is above the number line from the tick mark at zero to the tick mark at one.  The tape diagram is divided into seven parts. The first two parts are equal in size and shaded. The next four parts are equal in size and shaded. The seventh part is not shaded and not labeled. Together, the six shaded parts of the tape diagram are from the tick mark at zero to the left of the tick mark at one-half on the number line.

A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-half unit. A tape diagram is above the number line from the tick mark at zero to the tick mark at one.  The tape diagram is divided into seven parts. The first two parts are equal in size and shaded. The next four parts are equal in size and shaded. The seventh part is not shaded and not labeled. Together, the six shaded parts of the tape diagram are from the tick mark at zero to between the tick marks at one-half and 1 on the number line.

A number line labeled 0 to 2 with tick marks every one-half unit. A tape diagram is above the number line from the tick mark at zero to an unlabeled point between the tick marks at 1 and 1 and 1-half.  The tape diagram is divided into six parts. The first two parts are equal in size and shaded. The next 4 parts are shaded. Together, the six shaded parts of the tape diagram are from the tick mark at zero to the right of the tick mark at 1 on the number line.

hints.content: We can make an estimate by picturing each fraction:   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A tape diagram with two tapes of equal length. The top tape is divided into three equal parts with each part labeled one-third. The first two parts are shaded. The bottom tape is divided into five equal parts with each part labeled one-fifth. The first four parts are shaded. Below the diagram, a curved bracket across the tapes is labeled 1.

hints.content: To find the total amount of chocolate chips, we need to add $\tealE{\dfrac2{3}}$ and $\maroonE{\dfrac45}$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 6 parts. The first 2 parts are equal in size and each labeled one-third. The last 4 parts are equal in size and each labeled one-fifth. A curved bracket from the first part to partway through the fourth part is labeled 1.

hints.content: We can compare our sum to benchmarks like ${\dfrac12}$ and $1$:   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 2 with tick marks every one-half unit. A tape diagram is above the number line from the tick mark at 0 to a little left of the tick mark at 1 and one-half. The tape diagram is divided into 6 parts. The first 2 parts are equal in size and each labeled one-third. The last 4 parts are equal in size and each labeled one-fifth.

hints.content: Our sum is more than $1$.
The sum that shows more than $1$ bag is a reasonable estimate for the amount of chocolate chips Tony has.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 2 with tick marks every one-half unit. A tape diagram is above the number line from the tick mark at zero to an unlabeled point between the tick marks at 1 and 1 and 1-half.  The tape diagram is divided into six parts. The first two parts are equal in size and shaded. The next 4 parts are shaded. Together, the six shaded parts of the tape diagram are from the tick mark at zero to the right of the tick mark at 1 on the number line.

question.content: Easton mixed $\dfrac3{2}\text{ kg}$ of flour with $\dfrac{1}{6}\text{ kg}$ of sugar.   **Determine a reasonable estimate for the amount of flour and sugar combined.**

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-half unit. A tape diagram is above the number line from the tick mark at zero to the tick mark at one.  The tape diagram is divided into five parts. The first three parts are equal in size and shaded. The next part is shaded. The fifth part is not shaded and not labeled. Together, the five shaded parts of the tape diagram are from the tick mark at zero to the left of the tick mark at one-half on the number line.

A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-half unit. A tape diagram is above the number line from the tick mark at zero to the tick mark at one.  The tape diagram is divided into five parts. The first three parts are equal in size and shaded. The next part is shaded. The fifth part is not shaded and not labeled. Together, the five shaded parts of the tape diagram are from the tick mark at zero to between the tick marks at one-half and 1 on the number line.

A number line labeled 0 to 2 with tick marks every one-half unit. A tape diagram is above the number line from the tick mark at zero to an unlabeled point between the tick marks at 1 and 1-half and 2. The tape diagram is divided into 4 parts. The first three parts are equal in size and shaded. The next part is shaded. Together, the four shaded parts of the tape diagram are from the tick mark at zero to the right of the tick mark at 1 and 1-half on the number line.

hints.content: We can make an estimate by picturing each fraction:  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A tape diagram with two tapes of unequal length. The twice as long top tape is divided into four equal parts with each part labeled one-half. The first three parts are shaded. The shorter bottom tape is divided into six equal parts with each part labeled one-sixth. The first part is shaded. Below the diagram, a curved bracket across the bottom tape is labeled 1.

hints.content: To find the total amount of flour and sugar combined, we need to add $\tealE{\dfrac3{2}}$ and $\maroonE{\dfrac16}$.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 4 parts. The first 3 parts are equal in size, shaded, and each labeled one-half. The last part is shaded and labeled one-sixth. A curved bracket across the first two parts of the tape is labeled 1.

hints.content: We can compare our sum to benchmarks like ${\dfrac12}$ and $1$:  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 2 with tick marks every one-half unit. A tape diagram is above the number line from the tick mark at 0 to a little right of the tick mark at 1 and one-half. The tape diagram is divided into 4 parts. The first 3 parts are equal in size, shaded, and each labeled one-half. The last part is shaded and labeled one-sixth.

hints.content: Our sum is more than $1$.
The sum that shows more than $1\text{ kg}$ is a reasonable estimate for the amount of flour and sugar Easton has.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 2 with tick marks every one-half unit. A tape diagram is above the number line from the tick mark at zero to an unlabeled point between the tick marks at 1 and 1-half and 2. The tape diagram is divided into 4 parts. The first three parts are equal in size and shaded. The next part is shaded. Together, the four shaded parts of the tape diagram are from the tick mark at zero to the right of the tick mark at 1 and 1-half on the number line.

question.content: Aubrey used $\dfrac47\text{ liter}$ of paint for a mural in her room and $\dfrac{2}{10}\text{ liter}$ for a wall in her bathroom.  **Determine a reasonable estimate for the total amount of paint Aubrey used.**

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-half unit. A tape diagram is above the number line from the tick mark at zero to the tick mark at one.  The tape diagram is divided into seven parts. The first four parts are equal in size and shaded. The next two parts are equal in size and shaded. The seventh part is not shaded and not labeled. Together, the six shaded parts of the tape diagram are from the tick mark at zero to the left of the tick mark at one-half on the number line.

A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-half unit. A tape diagram is above the number line from the tick mark at zero to the tick mark at one.  The tape diagram is divided into seven parts. The first four parts are equal in size and shaded. The next two parts are equal in size and shaded. The seventh part is not shaded and not labeled. Together, the six shaded parts of the tape diagram are from the tick mark at zero to between the tick marks at one-half and 1 on the number line.

A number line labeled 0 to 2 with tick marks every one-half unit. A tape diagram is above the number line from the tick mark at zero to an unlabeled point between the tick marks at 1 and 1 and 1-half.  The tape diagram is divided into six parts. The first four parts are equal in size and shaded. The next two parts are equal in size and shaded. Together, the six shaded parts of the tape diagram are from the tick mark at zero to the right of the tick mark at 1 on the number line

hints.content: We can make an estimate by picturing each fraction:  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A tape diagram with two tapes of equal length. The top tape is divided into seven equal parts with each part labeled one-seventh. The first four parts are shaded. The bottom tape is divided into ten equal parts with each part labeled one-tenth. The first two parts are shaded. Below the diagram, a curved bracket across the tapes is labeled 1.

hints.content: To find the total amount of paint that Aubrey used, we need to add $\tealE{\dfrac47}$ and $\maroonE{\dfrac2{10}}$.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 7 parts. The first 4 parts are equal in size and each labeled one-seventh. The next 2 parts are equal in size and each labeled one-tenth. The last part is not shaded and not labeled. A curved bracket across the tape is labeled 1.

hints.content: We can compare our sum to benchmarks like ${\dfrac12}$ and $1$:  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-half unit. A tape diagram is above the number line from the tick mark at 0 to the tick mark at 1. The tape diagram is divided into 7 parts. The first 4 parts are equal in size and each labeled one-seventh. The next 2 parts are equal in size and each labeled one-tenth. The last part is not shaded and not labeled. Together, the six shaded parts of the tape diagram are from the tick mark at zero to an approximate halfway point between tick mark at one-half and tick mark at 1 of the number line.

hints.content: Our sum is more than $\dfrac12$ but less than $1$.
The sum that shows more than $\dfrac12\text{ liter}$ but less than $1\text{ liter}$ is a reasonable estimate for the total amount of paint Aubrey used.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-half unit. A tape diagram is above the number line from the tick mark at zero to the tick mark at one.  The tape diagram is divided into seven parts. The first four parts are equal in size and shaded. The next two parts are equal in size and shaded. The seventh part is not shaded and not labeled. Together, the six shaded parts of the tape diagram are from the tick mark at zero to between the tick marks at one-half and 1 on the number line.

question.content: Nevio mixed $\dfrac5{8}\text{ L}$ of water with $\dfrac14\text{ L}$ of orange juice.  **Select the true statement about the amounts of liquid Nevio mixed.**

options.content: One fraction is about $\dfrac12$ and the other is less than $\dfrac12$.

hints.content: We can make an estimate by picturing each fraction:  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A tape diagram with two tapes of equal length. The top tape is divided into eight equal parts with each part labeled one-eighth. The first five parts are shaded. The bottom tape is divided into four equal parts with each part labeled one-fourth. The first part is shaded. Below the diagram, a curved bracket across the tapes is labeled 1.

hints.content: Let's compare the fraction $\maroonE{\dfrac{5}{8}}$ to $\dfrac12$.  [[☃ image 1]]   $\maroonE{\dfrac{5}{8}}$ is about the same as $\dfrac12$.

images.alt: A tape diagram with two tapes of equal length. The top tape is divided into eight equal parts with each part labeled one-eighth. The first five parts are shaded. The bottom tape is divided into two equal parts with each part labeled one-half. The first part is shaded. Below the diagram, a curved bracket across the tapes is labeled 1.

hints.content: Let's compare the fraction $\purpleE{\dfrac{1}{4}}$ to $\dfrac12$.  [[☃ image 2]]   $\purpleE{\dfrac{1}{4}}$ is less than $\dfrac12$.

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 7 unequal parts. The first 5 parts are equal in size, and each is shaded, and labeled one-eighth. The sixth part is shaded and labeled one-fourth. The seventh part is not shaded and not labeled. A curved bracket across the tape is labeled 1.

A tape diagram with two tapes of equal length. The top tape is divided into four equal parts with each part labeled one-fourth. The first part is shaded. The bottom tape is divided into two equal parts with each part labeled one-half. The first part is shaded. Below the diagram, a curved bracket across the tapes is labeled 1.

hints.content: The true statement about the amounts of liquid Nevio mixed is:  The fraction $\dfrac{5}{8}$ is about $\dfrac12$, and $\dfrac{1}{4}$ is less than $\dfrac12$.

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-half unit. A tape diagram is above the number line from the tick mark at zero to the tick mark at one.  The tape diagram is divided into 7 unequal parts. The first 5 parts are equal in size, and each is shaded, and labeled one-eighth. The sixth part is shaded and labeled one-fourth. The seventh part is not shaded and not labeled. The first 5 shaded parts of the tape diagram are from the tick mark at zero to a little right of the tick mark at one-half of the number line. Together, the six shaded parts of the tape diagram are from the tick mark at zero to the left of the tick mark at one of the number line.

question.content: John measured two pieces of string. One piece measured $\dfrac7{12}\text{ m}$ and the other measured $\dfrac47\text{ m}$.  **Select the true statement about the lengths of John's string.**

options.content: Both fractions are more than $1$ whole.

hints.content: We can make an estimate by picturing each fraction:  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A tape diagram with two tapes of equal length. The top tape is divided into 12 equal parts with each part labeled one-twelfth. The first 7 parts are shaded. The bottom tape is divided into 7 equal parts with each part labeled one-seventh. The first 4 parts are shaded. Below the diagram, a curved bracket across the tapes is labeled 1.

hints.content: Let's compare the fraction $\maroonE{\dfrac{7}{12}}$ to $\dfrac12$.  [[☃ image 1]]   $\maroonE{\dfrac{7}{12}}$ is about the same as $\dfrac12$.

images.alt: A tape diagram with two tapes of equal length. The top tape is divided into twelve equal parts with each part labeled one-twelfth. The first seven parts are shaded. The bottom tape is divided into two equal parts with each part labeled one-half. The first part is shaded. Below the diagram, a curved bracket across the tapes is labeled 1.

hints.content: Let's compare the fraction $\purpleE{\dfrac{4}{7}}$ to $\dfrac12$.  [[☃ image 2]]   $\purpleE{\dfrac{4}{7}}$ is about the same as $\dfrac12$.

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 11 unequal parts. The first 7 parts are equal in size, and each is shaded, and labeled one-twelfth. The last 4 parts are equal in size, and each is shaded, and labeled one-seventh. A curved bracket across the first 10 parts is labeled 1.

A tape diagram with two tapes of equal length. The top tape is divided into seven equal parts with each part labeled one-seventh. The first four parts are shaded. The bottom tape is divided into two equal parts with each part labeled one-half. The first part is shaded. Below the diagram, a curved bracket across the tapes is labeled 1.

hints.content: The true statement about the lengths of John's string is:  Both fractions are about $\dfrac12$.

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 2 with tick marks every one-half unit. A tape diagram is above the number line from the tick mark at zero to a little right of the tick mark at one. The tape diagram is divided into 11 unequal parts. The first 7 parts are equal in size, shaded, and each labeled one-twelfth. The last 4 parts are equal in size, shaded, and each labeled one-seventh.

question.content: Bo feeds his dog twice a day. In the morning, he feeds the dog $\dfrac13\text{ kg}$ of dog food.  In the evening, he feeds the dog $\dfrac2{10}\text{ kg}$ of food.  **Select the true statement about the amount of food Bo feeds his dog.**

options.content: One fraction is about $\dfrac12$ and the other is about $1$.

hints.content: We can make an estimate by picturing each fraction:    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A tape diagram with two tapes of equal length. The top tape is divided into three equal parts with each part labeled one-third. The first part is shaded. The bottom tape is divided into ten equal parts with each part labeled one-tenth. The first two parts are shaded. Below the diagram, a curved bracket across the tapes is labeled 1.

hints.content: Let's compare the fraction $\maroonE{\dfrac{1}{3}}$ to $\dfrac12$.  [[☃ image 2]]   $\maroonE{\dfrac{1}{3}}$ is less than $\dfrac12$.

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 4 unequal parts. The first part is shaded and labeled one-third. The next 2 parts are equal in size, and each is shaded and labeled one-tenth. The last part is not shaded and not labeled. A curved bracket across the tape is labeled 1.

A tape diagram with two tapes of equal length. The top tape is divided into three equal parts with each part labeled one-third. The first part is shaded. The bottom tape is divided into two equal parts with each part labeled one-half. The first part is shaded. Below the diagram, a curved bracket across the tapes is labeled 1.

hints.content: Let's compare the fraction $\purpleE{\dfrac{2}{10}}$ to $\dfrac12$.  [[☃ image 1]]   $\purpleE{\dfrac{2}{10}}$ is less than $\dfrac12$.

images.alt: A tape diagram with two tapes of equal length. The top tape is divided into ten equal parts with each part labeled one-tenth. The first two parts are shaded. The bottom tape is divided into two equal parts with each part labeled one-half. The first part is shaded. Below the diagram, a curved bracket across the tapes is labeled 1.

hints.content: The true statement about the amount of food Bo feeds his dog is:   Both fractions are less than $\dfrac12$.

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-half unit. A tape diagram is above the number line from the tick mark at zero to the tick mark at one.  The tape diagram is divided into four parts. The first part is shaded and labeled one-third. The next two parts are equal in size, shaded, and each labeled one-tenth. The fourth part is not shaded and not labeled. Together, the three shaded parts of the tape diagram are from the tick mark at zero to a little right of the tick mark at one-half of the number line.

question.content: Liz ran $\dfrac45\text{ km}$ on Monday and $\dfrac56\text{ km}$ on Tuesday.  **Select the true statement about the distance Liz ran.**

options.content: One fraction is about $\dfrac12$ and the other is less than $\dfrac12$.

hints.content: We can make an estimate by picturing each fraction:  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A tape diagram with two tapes of equal length. The top tape is divided into five equal parts with each part labeled one-fifth. The first 4 parts are shaded. The bottom tape is divided into six equal parts with each part labeled one-sixth. The first 5 parts are shaded. Below the diagram, a curved bracket across the tapes is labeled 1.

hints.content: Let's compare the fraction $\maroonE{\dfrac{4}{5}}$ to $\dfrac12$.  [[☃ image 1]]   $\maroonE{\dfrac{4}{5}}$ is greater than $\dfrac12$. It is almost the same as $1$ whole.

images.alt: A tape diagram with two tapes of equal length. The top tape is divided into five equal parts with each part labeled one-fifth. The first four parts are shaded. The bottom tape is divided into two equal parts with each part labeled one-half. The first part is shaded. Below the diagram, a curved bracket across the tapes is labeled 1.

hints.content: Let's compare the fraction $\purpleE{\dfrac{5}{6}}$ to $\dfrac12$.  [[☃ image 2]]   $\purpleE{\dfrac{5}{6}}$ is greater than $\dfrac12$. It is   almost the same as $1$ whole.

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 9 unequal parts. The first 4 parts are equal in size, and each is shaded, and labeled one-fifth. The last 5 parts are equal in size, and each is shaded, and labeled one-sixth. A curved bracket across the first 5 parts and a portion of sixth part is labeled 1.

A tape diagram with two tapes of equal length. The top tape is divided into six equal parts with each part labeled one-sixth. The first five parts are shaded. The bottom tape is divided into two equal parts with each part labeled one-half. The first part is shaded. Below the diagram, a curved bracket across the tapes is labeled 1.

hints.content: The true statement about the distance Liz ran is:   Both fractions are almost $1$ whole.

question.content: Clara had $\dfrac{1}{2}\text{ L}$ of orange juice. Then she poured herself a glass and had $\dfrac16\text{ L}$ of orange juice left.  **Which number line shows a reasonable estimate of the amount of orange juice that went into Clara's glass ?**

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-half unit. A tape diagram with 2 tapes is above the number line from the tick mark at zero to the tick mark at one.  The top tape is divided into 2 equal parts. The first part is shaded. The second part is not shaded. The bottom tape is divided into 3 unequal parts. The first part is not shaded. The next part is shaded. The last part is not shaded. The right edges of the shaded parts of each tape line up with the tick mark at one-half on the number line. An arrow on the number line starts at 0 and ends at the left edge of the shaded part of the second tape. The arrow ends to the left of the tick mark at one-half on the number line.

A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-half unit. A tape diagram with 2 tapes is above the number line from the tick mark at zero to the tick mark at one.  The top tape is divided into 4 equal parts. The 3 parts are shaded. The fourth part is not shaded. The bottom tape is divided into 3 unequal parts. The first part is not shaded. The next part is shaded. The last part is not shaded. The right edges of the shaded parts of each tape line up to the right of the tick mark at one-half on the number line. An arrow on the number line starts at 0 and ends at the left edge of the shaded part of the second tape. The arrow ends to the right of the tick mark at one-half on the number line.

A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-half unit. A tape diagram with 2 tapes is above the number line from the tick mark at zero to the tick mark at one.  The top tape is divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is shaded. The second part is not shaded. The bottom tape is divided into 3 unequal parts. The first part is not shaded. The next part is shaded. The last part is not shaded. The right edges of the shaded parts of each tape line up to the left of the tick mark at one-half on the number line. An arrow on the number line starts at 0 and ends at the left edge of the shaded part of the second tape. The arrow ends to the right of the tick mark at 0 on the number line.

hints.content: We can make an estimate by picturing each fraction:  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A tape diagram with two tapes of equal length. The top tape is divided into 2 equal parts with each part labeled one-half. The first part is shaded. The bottom tape is divided into 6 equal parts with each part labeled one-sixth. The first part is shaded. Above the diagram, a curved bracket across the tapes is labeled 1.

hints.content: To find the amount of juice Clara poured, we need to subtract $\redE{\dfrac{1}{2}}$ and $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{6}}$.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt:
A tape diagram with two tapes of equal length. 
The top tape is divided into 2 equal parts. The first part is shaded and labeled one-half. The bottom tape is divided into 3 unequal parts. The first part is not shaded and not labeled. The next part is shaded and labeled one-sixth. The last part is not shaded and not labeled. The right edges of the shaded parts of each tape line up. A curved bracket across the tape is labeled 1.

hints.content: We can compare our difference to benchmarks like ${\dfrac12}$ and $1$:  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt:
A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-half unit. A tape diagram with 2 tapes is above the number line from the tick mark at zero to the tick mark at one.  
The top tape is divided into 2 equal parts. The first part is shaded and labeled one-half. 
The bottom tape is divided into 3 unequal parts. The first part is not shaded and not labeled. The next part is shaded and labeled one-sixth. The last part is not shaded and not labeled. The right edges of the shaded parts of each tape line up with the tick mark at one-half on the number line.
An arrow on the number line starts at 0 and ends at the left edge of the shaded part of the second tape. The arrow ends to the left of the tick mark at one-half on the number line.

hints.content: The difference that shows less than $\dfrac12\text{ L}$ is a reasonable estimate for the amount of juice Clara poured.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-half unit. A tape diagram with 2 tapes is above the number line from the tick mark at zero to the tick mark at one.  The top tape is divided into 2 equal parts. The first part is shaded. The second part is not shaded. The bottom tape is divided into 3 unequal parts. The first part is not shaded. The next part is shaded. The last part is not shaded. The right edges of the shaded parts of each tape line up with the tick mark at one-half on the number line. An arrow on the number line starts at 0 and ends at the left edge of the shaded part of the second tape. The arrow ends to the left of the tick mark at one-half on the number line.

question.content: Rayen had $\dfrac78\text{ kg}$ of flour for making bread. After using some, she had $\dfrac27\text{ kg}$ of flour remaining.   **Which number line shows a reasonable estimate of how much Rayen used?**

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-half unit. A tape diagram with 2 tapes is above the number line from the tick mark at zero to the tick mark at one.  The top tape is divided into 8 equal parts. The first 7 parts are shaded. The eighth part is not shaded. The bottom tape is divided into 4 unequal parts. The first part is not shaded. The next two parts are shaded. The last part is not shaded. The right edges of the shaded parts of each tape line up to the right of the tick mark at one-half on the number line. An arrow on the number line starts at 0 and ends at the left edge of the shaded part of the second tape. The arrow ends to the left of the tick mark at one-half on the number line.

A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-half unit. A tape diagram with 2 tapes is above the number line from the tick mark at zero to the tick mark at one. The top tape is divided into 8 parts. The first 7 parts are equal in size and are shaded. The eighth part is not shaded. The bottom tape is divided into 4 parts. The first part is not shaded. The next two parts are equal and shaded. The last part is not shaded. The right edges of the shaded parts of each tape line up. question.content: Avril had $\dfrac5{8}\text{ L}$ of milk before making pancakes. After pancakes, she had $\dfrac13\text{ L}$ of milk left.  **Select the true statement about the amounts of milk  Avril had for pancakes.**

options.content: One fraction is about $\dfrac12$ and the other is less than $\dfrac12$.

hints.content: We can make an estimate by picturing each fraction:  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A tape diagram with two tapes of equal length. The top tape is divided into eight equal parts with each part labeled one-eighth. The first five parts are shaded. The bottom tape is divided into three equal parts with each part labeled one-third. The first part is shaded. Below the diagram, a curved bracket across the tapes is labeled 1.

hints.content: Let's compare the fraction $\maroonE{\dfrac{5}{8}}$ to $\dfrac12$.  [[☃ image 1]]   $\maroonE{\dfrac{5}{8}}$ is about the same as $\dfrac12$.

images.alt: A tape diagram with two tapes of equal length. The top tape is divided into eight equal parts with each part labeled one-eighth. The first five parts are shaded. The bottom tape is divided into two equal parts with each part labeled one-half. The first part is shaded. Below the diagram, a curved bracket across the tapes is labeled 1.

hints.content: Let's compare the fraction $\purpleE{\dfrac{1}{3}}$ to $\dfrac12$.  [[☃ image 1]]   $\purpleE{\dfrac{1}{3}}$ is less than $\dfrac12$.

images.alt: A tape diagram with two tapes of equal length. The top tape is divided into eight equal parts with each part labeled one-eighth. The first five parts are shaded. The bottom tape is divided into two equal parts with each part labeled one-half. The first part is shaded. Below the diagram, a curved bracket across the tapes is labeled 1.

hints.content: The true statement about the amounts of milk  Avril had for pancakes is:  One fraction is about $\dfrac12$ and the other is less than $\dfrac12$.

question.content: Aiden had $\dfrac{9}{10}\text{ m}$ of fabric before sewing a dress for his friend. After sewing the dress, he had $\dfrac{6}{7}\text{ m}$ of fabric left.    **Select the true statement about the amount of fabric Aiden had.**

options.content: One fraction is about one-half and the other is almost 1 whole.
One fraction is about one-half and the other is almost $1$ whole.

hints.content: We can make an estimate by picturing each fraction:  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A tape diagram with two tapes of equal length. The top tape is divided into ten equal parts with each part labeled one-tenth. The first nine parts are shaded. The bottom tape is divided into seven equal parts with each part labeled one-seventh. The first part six parts are shaded. Below the diagram, a curved bracket across the tapes is labeled 1.

hints.content: Let's compare the fraction $\maroonE{\dfrac{9}{10}}$ to $\dfrac12$.  [[☃ image 1]]   $\maroonE{\dfrac{9}{10}}$ is about the same as $1$ whole.

images.alt: A tape diagram with two tapes of equal length. The top tape is divided into ten equal parts with each part labeled one-tenth. The first nine parts are shaded. The bottom tape is divided into two equal parts with each part labeled one-half. The first part is shaded. Below the diagram, a curved bracket across the tapes is labeled 1.

hints.content: Let's compare the fraction $\purpleE{\dfrac{6}{7}}$ to $\dfrac12$.  [[☃ image 1]]   $\purpleE{\dfrac{6}{7}}$ is about the same as $1$ whole.

images.alt: A tape diagram with two tapes of equal length. The top tape is divided into seven equal parts with each part labeled one-seventh. The first six parts are shaded. The bottom tape is divided into two equal parts with each part labeled one-half. The first part is shaded. Below the diagram, a curved bracket across the tapes is labeled 1.

hints.content: The true statement about the amount of fabric Aiden had is:  Both fractions are almost $1$ whole.

question.content: Priya had $\dfrac{2}{5}\text{ m}$ of ribbon before wrapping gifts. After wrapping the gifts, she had$\dfrac{1}{6}\text{ m}$ of ribbon left.    **Select the true statement about the amount of ribbon Priya had for presents.**

The bottom tape is divided into two equal parts with each part labeled one-half. The first part is shaded. Below the diagram, a curved bracket across the tapes is labeled 1.

The bottom tape is divided into two equal parts with each part labeled one-half. The first part is shaded. Below the diagram, a curved bracket across the tapes is labeled 1.

hints.content: The true statement about the amount of ribbon Priya had for presents:  Both fractions are less than $\dfrac12$.

question.content: Carlos had $\dfrac{6}{8}\text{ kg}$ of sugar before making cookies. After baking, he had $\dfrac{1}{4}\text{ kg}$ of sugar left.    **Select the true statement about the amounts of sugar Carlos had for cookies.**

options.content: One fraction is less than $\dfrac12$ and the other is almost $1$.

hints.content: We can make an estimate by picturing each fraction:  [[☃ image 1]]

The bottom tape is divided into two equal parts with each part labeled one-half. The first part is shaded. Below the diagram, a curved bracket across the tapes is labeled 1.

hints.content: Let's compare the fraction $\purpleE{\dfrac{1}{4}}$ to $\dfrac12$.  [[☃ image 1]]   $\purpleE{\dfrac{1}{4}}$ is less than $\dfrac12$.

The bottom tape is divided into two equal parts with each part labeled one-half. The first part is shaded. Below the diagram, a curved bracket across the tapes is labeled 1.

hints.content: The true statement about the amounts of sugar Carlos had for cookies:  One fraction is less than $\dfrac12$ and the other is almost $1$.
